author: Miranda Larbi
title: Bodyform is donating 200,000 packs of sanitary protection to help fight period poverty
text:
(Credit: Getty) Bodyform has just launched a three-year commitment to helping alleviate period poverty.
Last week, a charity came out to say that girls in the UK were resorting to using socks because they can’t afford sanitary products and that some were skipping school as a result .
Marathon training week 9: running while tied to someone else Freedom4Girls claimed that school kids were having to stuff toilet paper down their pants to stop themselves from bleeding through their clothes at school.
So now Bodyform has promised to donate 200,000 packs of sanitary products by 2020 to help thousands of women and girls get access to free period protection.
‘These latest reports are in line with research from our own Hygiene Matters report which found 40% of UK girls have felt that their period has kept them from leading a full and active life at school,’ explains SCA’s Marketing Director for Bodyform, Nicola Coronado.
(Picture: Jochen Tack/imageBROKER/REX/Shutterstock) ‘As a manufacturer of these essential products, we feel incredibly moved by this and we see this commitment as the first step in helping to combat these issues. Alongside campaigns such as The Homeless Period, we can overcome the taboo of talking about menstruation while ensuring sanitary products are reaching those most in need.
‘Until we know the full extent of this issue in the UK, we would urge other manufacturers to look at how they can further support this cause so that we can keep increasing access to these fundamental products.’
They’ll be sending towels to In Kind Direct who’ll then distribute packs through its network of 5,000 charitable organisations around the UK.

‘In Kind Direct distributes everyday essential products to charities across the UK, hundreds of which support women and girls affected by issues such as homelessness, poverty, disability, illness and domestic violence,’ says Robin Boles VO, CEO of In Kind Direct.
‘This very welcome, long term commitment from Bodyform means we will be able to provide more charities with a consistent supply of sanitary products and help many more women struggling to afford this most basic necessity.’
